--- Original Email ---From: Priscilla.Huh@bwater.comSubject: Bridgewater Associates | Oxford First Round InterviewDate: 2025-10-28T15:37:15+00:00
Content:
Hi Ryan,

I am excited to invite you to interview for the Bridgewater Associates Investment Associate Program.

My name is Priscilla, and I am a member of the recruiting team, working closely with your recruiter, {recruiter name}, cc'd.â€¯ We will be your main points of contact throughout the interview process.

We will be hosting first round interviews at The Randolph Hotel (Beaumont St, Oxford OX1 2LN, United Kingdom) during the day on Friday, October 31st. If you are selected to proceed to the next round interviews, you will be invited back to interview in person on Saturday, November 1st.
Please review the time slots below and reply all with every slot you are available to interview. Providing all available options will help us schedule efficiently.

Friday, October 31st
Saturday, November 1st
Slot 1: 9:00 â€“ 10:30 GMT
Slot 1: 9:00 - 10:00 GMT
Slot 2: 10:30 â€“ 12:00 GMT
Slot 2: 10:15 â€“ 11:15 GMT
Slot 3: 13:00 â€“ 14:30 GMT
Slot 3: 11:30 â€“ 12:30 GMT


  *   This interview will be an Analytics Discussion Group. In Investment Analytics, we deal with many complex theoretical problems with no clear right or wrong answer. The goal of the Discussion Group interview is to simulate the kind of conversations weâ€™d have around one of these problems. In this interview, we will assess your ability to develop a framework for evaluation of an open-ended question, integrate new ideas into your framework, and weigh tradeoffs when considering how to practically implement your ideas. Our interviewers will ask questions for the group to discuss. An example is: â€œIs television damaging to society?â€.
  *   Please hold a total of 1 hour and 30 minutes for the interview (1 hour 15 minutes for the interview with a 15-minute buffer).

  *   Someone will be in the lobby of the hotel to greet you and direct you to your interview room. You don't need to be particularly early, but please arrive about five minutes before your designated interview time.â€¯

  *   Dress is code is informal - no need to wear a suit!

  *   Let us know if you have any competing offers with upcoming deadlines. We will communicate with you on whether you are moving forward to next round interviews by end of day on Friday, October 31st.

  *   The Investment Associate role requires all candidates to be eligible to participate in our IA Class and subsequent training. This might mean some candidates might be ineligible for the position due to their current immigration status. If you have questions or concerns on this or your qualifications following your interview process, weâ€™d be happy to connect you with our Immigration team.

Social Event
We hope youâ€™ll join us for a social gathering on Thursday evening ahead of the interviews. Come enjoy some appetizers and drinks and get to know several members of our Investment Team.
Location: The Varsity Club (9A High St, Oxford OX1 4DB, United Kingdom)
Time: Thursday, October 30th, from 6:30â€“8:30 p.m. GMT â€” feel free to stop by whenever you can.
Details: Dress code is casual. All food and beverages will be covered by Bridgewater.

We will follow up with confirmation details prior to the interview. If you have any questions, please â€˜reply allâ€™ and one of us will get back to you as soon as possible!

Best,
Priscilla


----------------------------------------------------------------------
This message is intended exclusively for the individual(s) or entity to which it is addressed.  It may contain information that is proprietary, privileged or confidential or otherwise legally exempt from disclosure.  We do not waive any confidentiality by misdelivery.  If you are not the named addressee or if you receive this communication in error, you are not authorized to read, use, print, retain, copy or disseminate this message or any part of it.  Your acceptance of this communication constitutes your agreement to keep confidential all information contained herein, as well as any information derived by you from such information.  If you have received this message in error, please notify the sender immediately by e-mail and delete all electronic or paper copies of the message, including any attachments.Nothing in this email is intended to constitute (1) investment or trading advice or recommendations or any advertisement or (2) a solicitation of an investment in any jurisdiction in which such a solicitation would be unlawful.Please note that Bridgewater Associates, LP, including its affiliates, reserves the right to intercept, archive, monitor and review all communications to and from its network.

DearÂ Priscilla,

I was wondering whether there is a possibility of any alternative options if these days for interviews don't work well for me. Apologies for any inconvenience.

Many thanks,

Ryan

messages.content:
You are writing an email. Context: Recipient: sbhatta2@caltech.edu; Subject: Re: Project paper plan; Date: 2025-10-27T20:09:53+00:00

This is a reply to an email from sbhatta2@caltech.edu dated 2025-10-27T18:05:55+00:00 with subject 'Re: Project paper plan':
--- Original Email ---From: sbhatta2@caltech.eduSubject: Re: Project paper planDate: 2025-10-27T18:05:55+00:00
Content:
Hello Ryan,

Great to know that you are still interested. It would be very useful to get these out and set the stage for others to use your algorithm for a broader search and classification.

Regarding the paper, I would recommend you treating it as a report for now. So maybe you can write everything you feel like. After that I will give it a read and ask you questions, which will lead to inclusion or exclusion of contents.

No need for polishing language now. I would suggest not to worry about the length, as the reception of the work has nothing to do with it. Moreover, people are more likely to read short and concise papers than long papers. I have done the mistake of packing a lot of stuff in a single paper, and making it long. Then I have seen people missing out sections of the paper. I would thus advise against it.

I would guess a majority of the paper to be on the selection of the region, analysis of the recovered HASH PNe (understanding any size biases etc, like the plots you have been making) etc. I think we are yet to decide on a well defined region on the sky and run the algorithm? Maybe we can do that.

Regarding spectroscopy, I am still waiting on the blue channel data (where OIII etc lines lies). NGPS blue side will be on soon, and someone else observed a few of your targets with Keck/LRIS (I am yet to receive the data from them). But I can write it down quickly, whenever I get them.

My suggestion would be to get something out before your graduation, so that it helps both with your future applications (job or grad school). I will have enough data over the next year. But we can aim to get the rest of the paper done by then.

We can possibly chat a bit and set a timeline? Let me know when you would be free. Absolutely no rush!

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee



On Oct 27, 2025, at 10:23â€¯AM, Ryan Lin <ryanlin10@gmail.com> wrote:

Hi Soumyadeep,

Hope everything is going well! I'm still hoping to work on the paper, but just have been quite busy with coursework coming into the new term.

Was planning on dedicating more time once the spectroscopy results from our existing candidates were confirmed to be positive/interesting. What are the updates on this?

Any recommendations on what section of the paper to work on first? Previously, when writing the introduction I was struggling to think of things to fill the paper with, since many of the techniques we used could be described quite compactly.

Warm regards,
Ryan



On Mon, Oct 27, 2025 at 16:45:16, Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee <sbhatta2@caltech.edu<mailto:sbhatta2@caltech.edu>> wrote:

Hello Ryan,

Hope you are doing well. I was wondering if you are still willing to work on the paper from your project? No worries if you have been busy with your courseworks and other projects. Just wanted to know your plans. Please reply at your convenience.

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee



--- End Original Email ---

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Hi Soumyadeep,

Awesome sounds good. Want to specialise into some sort of computational science/data science/machine learning research in either academia or industry so would be great getting something out.

Would any of the following times work?

https://calendly.com/ryanlin10/30min

Warm regards,

Ryan

Content:
Hi Everyone!

Just in case you weren't aware and didn't get this email yesterday: *The final deadline for the Oxbridge AI Challenge 2025 is TODAY at midnight.* You've got just under 5 hours left if you want to update your application and improve it.

If you missed the email please see your spam. We sent it via udai@tuki.today. Sending via this account just to make sure we can get passed the spam filter for some of you.

For those who are not ware we've been sharing our application system (and fixing bugs and helping lots of people with their applications). *Unless you're really struggling, please apply via the system at* *oxbridgeaichallenge.com* ( http://oxbridgeaichallenge.com/ ) *as well.*

Otherwise, we as a team will need to manually check and move applications from one system to the other.

ğŸ“Š *Explaining Why Weâ€™re Asking*

To give you an idea: *125 startups applied just via the Typeform alone.* So that can take us up to a day to go through and check before we can start letting judges get access to things. The Oxbridge AI Challenge logistically is a coordinated effort between over 400/500 people. Itâ€™s not easy.

*Need us to share your application with you! No problem!*

If you don't remember what you submitted, we can help you - just ask us! We've done this for over 15 startups today. You're already submitted so you didn't miss the deadline. So youâ€™re in already no stress.

ğŸ’¡ *Think of This as an Opportunity*

Apologies for the inconvenience but this is a chance to improve your application! But no worries if you don't get a chance to. *Any requests to do this after midnight today will not be accepted* and we'll update things to the best of our ability.While you do definitely check out the FAQ!

Applying via our platform makes it much faster and easier to coordinate with judges and helps us speed things up after the deadline.

ğŸ› *Bugs Fixed!*

For those who chose to apply via Typeform because of bugs, note we've fixed:

* âœ… CV upload issues

* âœ… Pitch deck upload problems

* âœ… Team joining issues

* âœ… And more!

ğŸ‘¥ *Team Issues? Here's the Fix*

If you or your team members weren't getting emails or struggling to join teams:

* The owner should *remove them first*

* Then *send out the invite again*

If you're struggling to log in, just refresh and try again.

ğŸ“š *Resources Available*

There's an *FAQ link* via the platform and the oxbridgeaichallenge.com ( http://oxbridgeaichallenge.com/ ) page. Please check it out - there's a *rubric* there that might help!

âœ¨ *Platform Benefits*

* ğŸ¤ Use *voice to fill things out* (especially useful for dyslexics!)

* ğŸ’¾ *Save your progress* as you go

ğŸ™ *A Note on Quality*

It's a bit buggy, but we're getting there. In the words of Reid Hoffman: "If you're not embarrassed when you launch, then you launched too late." I'll let you decide how we've been feeling ğŸ˜…

ğŸ• *Final Reminder*

*Remember:* If for any reason you decide not to update your application, no worries. Weâ€™re still here for you and we'll migrate it for you. But with the number of applications we received via Typeform (125+!), *any help from you would be most appreciated!*

*Wishing you all the very best of luck!*

You've got this, and We've Got Your Back!

Big hugs,

Udai and the Oxbridge AI Challenge Team!

P.S. If you've already done this please ignore!

--- Original Email ---From: info@oxai.orgSubject: OxAI - Week 1 Winter 2025Date: 2025-10-13T14:05:02+00:00
Content:
https://oxai.org


** OxAI | Whatâ€™s New
------------------------------------------------------------

Week 1

Keep innovating, AI for the benefit of everyone

EVENT

OxAI x QuantCo Dinner

23 October
https://jobs.lever.co/quantco-/87a445f6-c8b4-4b15-8034-48d49ee05d1c
SIGN UP (https://jobs.lever.co/quantco-/87a445f6-c8b4-4b15-8034-48d49ee05d1c)

EVENT

CODE&LAW HACKATHON

AI & Dispute Resolution

OxAI | Arbtech

Date: 15 November 2025 (Registration Deadline: 25 October)

Time: 9am - 7pm

Location: Pichette Auditorium, Pembroke College, University of Oxford

Join the OxAI and ArbTech.io for a one-day Hackathon focused on developing innovative AI solutions for real-world challenges in Dispute Resolution (Litigation, Arbitration, Mediation, Negotiation etc.).

This event is hosted in collaboration with Oxbridge-AIx and the Singapore Global Network (SGN) and welcomes students and professionals from all disciplines.

If you're a lawyer or law student trying to grasp the new legal tech landscape but haven't found the right entry point yet, or a computer scientist/developer aiming to understand the paths to the legal market, this will be a great opportunity to learn more, connect, and engage with experts across diverse fields and contribute to bridging the gap between law and computer science.

ğŸ“Œ No coding is required to participate.

Inquiries: lana.seo@oxai.org, fernanda.dias@oxai.org, hello@arbtech.io

If you want to join our team and start your journey in AI in Oxford, we are still recruiting for the committee roles for 25/26. You can apply below, the applications are on a rolling basis.

New:

We have opened up applications for 3 new teams
* Sponsorship, Partnerships and Careers,
* Diversity & Inclusion,
* Labs

Sponsorship, Partnerships and Careers:

The team works on managing society fundraising, establishing and maintaining our existing partnerships and organizing career oriented events for the students in the ecosystem. We are looking for individuals with past fundraising experience and strong network reach.

Diversity and Inclusion:

The team runs the annual mentorship scheme pairing students from under-represented backgrounds with industry mentors.

Labs:

The team runs both hardware and software focused research projects. We are looking for team individuals with a strong publishing and leadership experience to lead each of our 4 research projects. The projects include an embodied AI, NVIDIA/AMD GPU optimization, software research in partnership with Mistral AI.

*Only apply to this role if you are interested in leading the research project*

Applications to the Events & Media and Safety & Governance teams are still open.

Eligibility:

All students currently enrolled at the University of Oxford are eligible to apply, irrespective of academic background. You have to be a current student to apply.

*OxAI Podcast*

*ğŸ™ New Episode Alert!*

We are delighted to welcome Professor Kristin Persson, a leading figure in computational materials science and the founding director of the Materials Project at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. Prof. Perssonâ€™s work integrates physics, chemistry, and machine learning to accelerate materials discovery, while strongly advocating for open science as a driver of scientific progress and innovation.

*Episode Highlights:*

ğŸ§ª The Materials Project â€” A cornerstone for ML-driven materials discovery

ğŸŒ Open Science â€” We Can All Become Innovation Multipliers

APPLICATIONS
------------

*Go Further Together*
---------------------

If you want to join our team and start your journey in AI in Oxford, we are still recruiting for the committee roles for 25/26. You can apply below, the applications are on a rolling basis.

*New:*

We have opened up applications for 3 new teams

* 

Sponsorship , Partnerships and Careers ,

* 

Diversity & Inclusion,

* 

Labs

*Sponsorship, Partnerships and Careers:*

The team works on managing society fundraising, establishing and maintaining our existing partnerships and organizing career oriented events for the students in the ecosystem. We are looking for individuals with past fundraising experience and strong network reach.

*Diversity and Inclusion:*

The team runs the annual mentorship scheme pairing students from under-represented backgrounds with industry mentors.

*Labs:*

The team runs both hardware and software focused research projects. We are looking for team individuals with a strong publishing and leadership experience to lead each of our 4 research projects. The projects include an embodied AI, NVIDIA/AMD GPU optimization, software research in partnership with Mistral AI.

*Only apply to this role if you are interested in leading the research project*

Applications to the *Events & Media* and *Safety & Governance* teams are still open.

*Eligibility:*

All students currently enrolled at the University of Oxford are eligible to apply, irrespective of academic background. You have to be a current student to apply.

APPLY NOW ( https://oxai.us19.list-manage.com/track/click?u=99260f22dbf0cc19dd6ad19bd&id=a6176ee3a6&e=6ae2873ea0 )

Outside OxAI

*OXBRIDGE AI X x IMPERIAL
* CO-FOUNDER MATCHMAKING POTLUCK DINNER

( https://oxai.us19.list-manage.com/track/click?u=99260f22dbf0cc19dd6ad19bd&id=2d2a77a4cb&e=6ae2873ea0 )

*Date:* 16 October 2025

*Time:* 7pm

*Location:* HQ, SW10, London

Join us for a Co-Founder Matchmaking potluck dinner bringing together the most ambitious entrepreneurs from Oxford, Cambridge, and Imperial College London. Just in time to apply for the Oxbridge AI Challenge!

Cross-Pollinate: Ideas. Connections. Opportunities.

In one room, we're uniting three of the UK's most vibrant startup ecosystems. Meet potential co-founders building in AI, deeptech, and emerging technologies. Form teams ahead of the Oxbridge AI Challenge deadline ( 20th October - Â£60k in equity-free prizes!).

This is a curated potluck-style event with limited capacity - 10 people from each university. Bring a dish to share and connect over meaningful conversations!

SIGN UP ( https://oxai.us19.list-manage.com/track/click?u=99260f22dbf0cc19dd6ad19bd&id=cd40a75587&e=6ae2873ea0 )

*EVENT*

*Mastery | Why Deeper Learning is Essential in an Age of Distraction*

*Date:* 14 October 2025

*Time:* 2 - 3pm

*Location:* Online & In-person, Levett Room - Wolfson College

Join us for a fireside chat with Ulrik Juul Christensen M.D, co-author of Mastery: Why Deeper Learning is Essential in an Age of Distraction written with Tony Wagner. ( https:/ / lnkd. in/ eM4KfMZm ( https://lnkd.in/eM4KfMZm ) )

We live in a time when information is everywhere, yet deep understanding feels harder to sustain. Does this change what, how, and why we learn? How are teachersâ€™ roles evolving? From sources of information - to sources of inspiration.

Together, weâ€™ll explore research and practice; why deeper learning is more essential than ever, how AI is reshaping education, and what it means to stay human and reimagine learning in a digital age.

This is a reply to an email from aam@astro.caltech.edu dated 2025-09-04T01:53:51+00:00 with subject 'Re: Questions about ML PNe Detection':
--- Original Email ---From: aam@astro.caltech.eduSubject: Re: Questions about ML PNe DetectionDate: 2025-09-04T01:53:51+00:00
Content:
Hi Ryan,

I'm on vacation this week and may not be able to get back to you soon on this. Keep me posted with what you do ...

Ashish

Get Outlook for Android<https://aka.ms/AAb9ysg>
________________________________
From: Ryan Lin <ryanlin10@gmail.com>
Sent: Wednesday, September 3, 2025 9:40:51 PM
To: Mahabal, Ashish <aam@astro.caltech.edu>
Cc: Bhattacharjee, Soumyadeep <sbhatta2@caltech.edu>
Subject: Questions about ML PNe Detection

Dear Ashish,

I've been working on building the training data collection and model training pipeline, and now have a simple 3x64x64 CNN trained from a small training set (with the dihedral transformation variants we discussed). I hope to carry on working on the ML side of the project for the time being so we still have time beyond this week!

I had a few questions that have come up:

- Continuous/discrete classification: I noticed Karan's classification CNN outputs discrete classifications (rather than continuous [0, 1]). Would a continuous classification (representing some sort of probability/confidence) work better for our purposes?

- Loss function: Related to the above, what would be the best loss function for either of the two cases? I see Karan uses cross entropy loss for the discrete classification. What would be the best loss function for the continuous case?

- CNN input size for large scale nebulae: Although most nebulae get captured in 64x64 snippets, quite a significant proportion lie outside of this size. At the moment I've just included cropped images of the larger nebulae in the training data, and hope the model learns to pick up on the features. Should I increase the snippet size 128x128?[cid:3c05fec6-cf27-44e4-a072-cd7f92142884]
- GPU: If we were to increase the snippet or model size, computation would start getting longer, especially on the cluster I'm currently using which has no GPU. I was wondering whether there are any remote GPUs/clusters I could use.
- Data quality: At the moment my data collection is quite crude. 33% of my snippets are true pne from hash, 33% are random snippets of the background sky, and 33% are false positives picked up from our original algorithm (mostly bad subtractions, other Ha emitters). I was wondering whether you had insight into constructing a higher quality dataset.

Warm regards,
Ryan





--- End Original Email ---

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Hi Ashish,

Was wondering whether you had any thoughts about this. I hope to continue working on developing a more sophisticated computer vision model to publish an additional follow-up paper to our current algorithm.

Warm regards,

Ryan

- Continuous/discrete classification: I noticed Karan's classification CNN outputs discrete classifications (rather than continuous [0, 1]). Would a continuous classification (representing some sort of probability/confidence) work better for our purposes?

- Loss function: Related to the above, what would be the best loss function for either of the two cases? I see Karan uses cross entropy loss for the discrete classification. What would be the best loss function for the continuous case?

- CNN input size for large scale nebulae: Although most nebulae get captured in 64x64 snippets, quite a significant proportion lie outside of this size. At the moment I've just included cropped images of the larger nebulae in the training data, and hope the model learns to pick up on the features. Should I increaseÂ the snippet size 128x128?

- GPU: If we were to increase the snippet or model size, computation would start getting longer, especially on the clusterÂ I'm currently using which hasÂ no GPU. I was wondering whether there are any remote GPUs/clusters I could use.

- Data quality: At the moment my data collection is quite crude. 33% of my snippets are true pneÂ from hash, 33% are random snippets of the background sky, and 33% are false positives picked up from our original algorithm (mostly bad subtractions, other Ha emitters). I was wondering whether you had insight into constructing a higher quality dataset.

Warm regards,

Ryan

Dear Dave,

I had a few things to mention before our meeting tomorrow:

First, I was wondering if you had the chance to look into the new feature on the website that shows the original two pairs in the detection.

Second, I was quite confused why the candidates in the original data I sent (RA 250-290 DEC 10-20) continued until object id 1849, after which it transitions to the second set of data I sent (RA 310-360), when there were only 924 objects in the csv file. This could be a glitch in the website?

I was also wondering whether we could load the following candidates to a separate page (or add a button that allows us to select what objects we want to view) to avoid confusion with the prior candidates (so something like before doesn't happen again). Open to any other suggestions though.

Also, I have stored the image files for each run in different folders, so it may be easier to create a separate webpage for each run.

For the RA 270-285 DEC minus 15 - 0 run, the image directory is:
/scr2/rxlin/old_code/pne_images_ra270p0to285p0_decminus15p0to0p0
with the respective csv file attached below. This uses my new crosschecking algorithm so there should be significantly fewer junks.

For the RA 240-310 DEC 10-30 run, the image directory is:
/scr2/rxlin/old_code/pne_images_ra240p0to310p0_dec10p0to30p0
with two respective csv file attached below (the one starting with pne_candidates is the file generated from the vanilla run and the one starting with crosschecker is the file generated after passing through my crosschecking algorithm).

My crosschecking algorithm is still running for this field and I have attached the results its generated thus far. I tweaked the detection thresholds in the vanilla run hence why the number of candidates in the vanilla run cvs file is so large (~15000). This has improved completeness to around 60%. The hope is that the crosschecker algorithm will significantly bring down the total candidate number (empirically it has only retained 4.43% of candidates in the vanilla csv file so far) whilst leaving true PNe untouched.

Many thanks,
Ryan

I realised made some slight errors with the run region diagram I made earlier. The corrected one is attached. Soumyadeep and I decided to perform the next run in the region labelled run 5. The crosschecker for this region is running overnight and should be done tomorrow.

Just a few questions too:

- Soumyadeep and I were wondering how your HASH database query on the website worked. In particular, what version and kind of the HASH databaseÂ is it using, and what do all the possible symbols mean. We've noticed cases where objects are showing up on the HASH database when they haven't been decisivelyÂ classified as planetary nebulae (e.g. HH)

- Particularly atÂ low galactic lattitudes, large nebula structures are a major source of junk. To classify these faster I was wondering whether you could add a new feature on the website: add zoomed out (400x400 pixels?) Ha1 images for each candidate.

- I noticed the Ha1 and Ha2 stacks are gone from the website. Could these be added again. We can perhaps replace the Ha3 and Ha4 stacks with these since Ha1 and Ha2 are more important for our purposes.

- There have been cases where we have an obvious planetary nebula candidate is not on the HASH database, however have been classified by either Gaia or SimbadÂ as some other object. I was wondering how reliable Gaia and SimbadÂ are? Do they use automated classification? How frequent do they classify realÂ PNeÂ as other objects like Y*, Be*, HS, Mi, Eb, Em*?

Warm regards,

Ryan

You are writing an email. Context: Recipient: dcook@ipac.caltech.edu; Subject: Agenda for Meeting; Date: 2025-08-15T07:54:00+00:00

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Dear Dave,

I had a few things to mention before our meeting tomorrow :

First, I was wondering if you had the chance to look into the new feature on the website that shows the original two pairs in the detection.

Second, I was quite confused why the candidates in the originalÂ data I sent ( RA 250-290 DEC 10 -20 ) continued until object id 1849, after which it transitions to the second set of data I sent (RA 310-360), when there were only 924 objects in the csvÂ file. This could be a glitch in the website?

I was also wondering whether we could load the following candidates to a separate page (or add a button that allows us to select what objects we want to view) to avoid confusion with the prior candidates (so something like before doesn't happen again). Open to any other suggestions though.

Also, I have stored the image files for each run in different folders, so it may be easier to create a separate webpage for each run.

For the RA 270-285 DEC minus 15 - 0 run, the image directory is:

/scr2/rxlin/old_code/pne_images_ra270p0to285p0_decminus15p0to0p0

with the respective csvÂ file attached below. This uses my new crosschecking algorithm so there should be significantly fewer junks.

For the RA 240-310 DEC 10 -30 run, the image directory is:

/scr2/rxlin/old_code/pne_images_ra240p0to310p0_dec10p0to30p0

withÂ two respective csvÂ file attached below (the one starting with pne_candidates is the file generated from the vanilla run and the one starting with crosscheckerÂ is the file generated after passing through my crosschecking algorithm).

My crosschecking algorithm is still runningÂ for this field and I have attached the results its generated thus far. I tweaked the detection thresholds in the vanilla run hence why the number of candidates in the vanilla run cvsÂ file is so large (~15000). This has improved completeness to around 60%. The hope is that the crosschecker algorithm will significantly bring down the total candidate number (empirically it has only retained 4.43% of candidates in the vanilla csvÂ file so far) whilst leaving true PNeÂ untouched.

Many thanks,

Ryan

Content:

Hi Ryan,

It should be possible to meet today/tomorrow, but many things are going 
on, so let us decide the time later.
What is your availability?

Please remind me your github id - I will ask Karan to add you. That may 
be the simplest.

H1 H2 images being of the same PN are spatially related. So a layered 
CNN would also make sense.
In the images, please use zscaling. Raw scaling will be overwhelmed by 
faintest and brightest pixels. You don't have to write out PNGs and read 
them for CNNs. You should use use npy files read in once and manipulate 
them. It may be OK to write out a zscaled .npy once and in future read 
that during trainings.

Yes, imbalance is important.Â  Use only twice or thrice as many non-PN 
images as PN images.
Imbalance within PN subtypes is important too. You may have to go for 
some hierarchy, or go after the dominant types.
We often do multiple binary classifiers too (independent).
Your subtypes do not add up to 100%, BTW.
What you refer to as quasi-stellar, are the QSOs, or quasi-stellar PN? 
(What does that mean?)

-ashish

Content:

HI Ryan,

Sorry, it took a bit longer for me to get back. Some responses to your 
plan are inline:

> - Our goal is to find new planetary nebulae in the CLU (census of the 
> local universe) dataset, consisting of images of most of the Northern 
> Sky above around minus 20 degrees declination. These images contain 
> four narrowband H-alpha filters for each part of the sky.
>
Yes. Please mention how many are known, and how many are expected of the 
different subtypes, and some stats on sizes (in terms of major/minor axes).

> - Segment anything model (SAM) is too slow to be used effectively
>
With a GPU it should be fast. We should try that before excluding.

> - We will use a CNN (or some other better performing architecture) 
> instead, taking 64x64 pixel images as input, outputting either a 
> probability or binary outcome (0, 1), corresponding to whether the 
> image contains a planetary nebula.
>
[0,1] (to include 0 and 1.

> - The CNN will take 3 images (background subtracted Ha1, Ha2, and 
> difference).
>
Use the 3 images as layers in a datacube. You can also try concatenating 
them. 2D CNNs can be simpler.

> - Training data will be 64x64 snippets of known planetary nebulae from 
> the HASH database. We will take 128x128 snippets first, then random 
> choose 64x64 cutouts within these, with rotations and reflections.
>
It may be more prudent to take something like 112x112 so that 64x64 
crops thereof do not have more than half the nebula cutoff in some cases.
You take 1-4 such instances per nebula, take rotations and reflections.

For the non-nebula cases take random 64x64 areas that do not contain a 
nebula. No reflections etc. needed.

Let us look at loss curves. Use a simple architecture to start with, but 
do good visualizations so that modifications can be made quickly.

-ashish

Hi Ashish,

I was wondering whether you'd be free to meet tomorrow or Friday.

Out of all known PNe (3964 in total):

- 76.1% have a major diameter less than 64 arcseconds

- 63.98% have a major diameter less than 32 arcseconds

- 45.3% have a major diameter less than 16 arcseconds

- 24.2% have a major diameter less than 8 arcseconds

- Can be mostly classified into the following categories:

Elliptical (36.9%), round (17%), bipolar (19.7%), irregular (~1%), asymmetric (~1%), quasi-stellar (13.4%).

- The vast majority are

I've done some research and found that a 2D CNN may be better for our purposes given the 3 inputs (Ha1, Ha2, and difference) are independent and have no spatial or temporal relation to each other.

I've created a few thousand positive and negative snippets of planetary nebulae for the training set. I've attachedÂ png representations for a random positive and negative snippet. Given on an actual search run, the proportion of instances of a planetary nebula being in the 64x64 fields would likely be <<1%, I was wondering whether you had any recommendations on the class imbalance handling during training.

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Hi Ashish,

Sending this again in case you didn't see it - experimenting with a new email app.

Last week's meeting summary:

- Our goal is to find new planetary nebulae in the CLU (census of the local universe) dataset, consisting of images of most of the Northern Sky above around minus 20 degrees declination. These images contain four narrowband H-alpha filters for each part of the sky.

- Segment anything model (SAM) is too slow to be used effectively

- We will use a CNN (or some other better performing architecture) instead, taking 64x64 pixel images as input, outputting either a probability or binary outcome (0, 1), corresponding to whether the image contains a planetary nebula.

- The CNN will take 3 images (background subtracted Ha1, Ha2, and difference).

- Training data will be 64x64 snippets of known planetary nebulae from the HASH database. We will take 128x128 snippets first, then random choose 64x64 cutouts within these, with rotations and reflections.

I will be in caltech the whole day today - would be happy to discuss with the visitor.

Warm regards,

Ryan

With regards to SAM, the following authors fine-tuned SAM on medical images, resulting in some performance increases:

https://openreview.net/pdf?id=BNrWHF5ZlC

The issue with SAM is that it only allows points and boxes as prompts, with no natural language prompting. It either outputs prompt-based masks, or unprompted masks (produces one masks for every object identified in an image). My intuition suggests weâ€™d have to generate unprompted masks for our use-case.

An issue Iâ€™ve been facing in general with the current algorithm is the shear amount of junk detection. This has primarily been due to unmasked stars which remain after subtraction (due to poor chip quality on the edges), cosmic rays, and various other transient phenomena.

I have 5 weeks left on SURF and would appreciate if you could set me concrete goals to complete each week.

I would encourage you to meet with Ashish and evaluate the two options.

Ashish, I would request you to let Ryan know your availability this week so that he can meet and discuss with you. I am away this week, but I will catch up next week.

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee

BTW, I just recalled that after my OVRO presentation at Shriâ€™s thinkshop last year, Liam Connor suggested using Segment Anything Method (SAM): https://segment-anything.com/ . Again, I do not have a good idea how we can do that and which one would be better.

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee

-ashish

-ashish

On 7/11/25 12:59 PM, Bhattacharjee, Soumyadeep wrote:
Hello Ashish,

Hope you are doing well.

I was wondering if you are around to meet sometime today or early next week with me and Ryan (cc-ed, me and Shriâ€™s SURF student). As I had mentioned to you, he is working on the CLU data to find nebulae. Currently he is using my non-ML code to discover a few objects, but in about a week or so we will be starting with building a ML version of it.

The paper/method that I had in mind is this: https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article/528/3/4733/7492281?login=true. Ryan will execute it and I will learn in the process.

If we could meet with you sometime soon, that would be awesome. I would request you to let us know your availabilities.

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee

>>> concrete goals to complete each week.
>>>
>>> Let me know your thoughts.
>>>
>>> Many thanks,
>>> Ryan

You are writing an email. Context: Recipient: sbhatta2@caltech.edu; Subject: Re: Meet for applying ML to CLU for nebulae; Date: 2025-08-05T22:22:21-07:00

This is a reply to an email from sbhatta2@caltech.edu dated 2025-08-06T03:48:15+00:00 with subject 'Re: Meet for applying ML to CLU for nebulae':
--- Original Email ---From: sbhatta2@caltech.eduSubject: Re: Meet for applying ML to CLU for nebulaeDate: 2025-08-06T03:48:15+00:00
Content:
Hello Ryan,

It is very unfortunate that Q Parker et al never got back regarding their AI model (I had not expected this). As I mentioned, there are two options. 1) try using SAM, 2) try to build your own CNN for the images. In either of (or both) the cases, Ashish would be the best person to help you. I would encourage you to meet with Ashish and evaluate the two options.

Ashish, I would request you to let Ryan know your availability this week so that he can meet and discuss with you. I am away this week, but I will catch up next week.

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee


On Jul 12, 2025, at 10:32â€¯PM, Bhattacharjee, Soumyadeep <sbhatta2@caltech.edu> wrote:

Hello Ashish,

Tuesday 4 PM works for me.

We can definitely contact the authors if needed. But I was thinking maybe we can have a first meeting among ourselves and evaluate the paper a bit. In any case the coming week I think we will be working mainly on my (non-ML segmentation) code. So if we are meeting on Tuesday, we can email the authors after the meeting.

BTW, I just recalled that after my OVRO presentation at Shriâ€™s thinkshop last year, Liam Connor suggested using Segment Anything Method (SAM): https://segment-anything.com/ . Again, I do not have a good idea how we can do that and which one would be better.

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee

On Jul 11, 2025, at 4:12â€¯PM, Mahabal, Ashish <aam@astro.caltech.edu> wrote:


Hi Ryan,

Great. I don't think we need a "proposal" :-)
That was me trying to say "presentation" - and that does not have to be a formal one.
Mainly for me to understand where we are.

If you can, do please go ahead ant contact the authors.

Meet on Tuesday at 4?

-ashish

On 7/11/25 3:22 PM, Ryan Lin wrote:
Dear Ashish,

I am very proficient in python and have undertaken several ML projects in the past (time series forecasting, computer vision, llm fine-tuning, stochastic prediction using random forests). I am familiar with all the main python ML packages.

I tried searching for the code on the mentioned PaperData Repository but could not find it - we may have to contact the authors.

How much detail would you want in the proposal?

Warm regards,
Ryan

On 11 Jul 2025, at 14:29, Ashish Mahabal <aam@astro.caltech.edu> wrote:


Hi Soumyadeep/Ryan,

Next week would be better. Tuesday afternoon, for instance.

Ryan, how much of an experience do you have with ML and python?
The linked paper claims that data and code are available.
It would be useful if it is downloaded and looked through.

Similarly, is your dataset and problem description ready?
It will be useful to start with a ten-minute outline of the proposal.

-ashish

On 7/11/25 12:59 PM, Bhattacharjee, Soumyadeep wrote:
Hello Ashish,

Hope you are doing well.

I was wondering if you are around to meet sometime today or early next week with me and Ryan (cc-ed, me and Shriâ€™s SURF student). As I had mentioned to you, he is working on the CLU data to find nebulae. Currently he is using my non-ML code to discover a few objects, but in about a week or so we will be starting with building a ML version of it.

The paper/method that I had in mind is this: https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article/528/3/4733/7492281?login=true. It uses a technique called Swin-Transformer, which I understand as a concept but I am not proficient enough to guide Ryan. I would request your help with this. We would like to work with you on this. Ryan will execute it and I will learn in the process.

If we could meet with you sometime soon, that would be awesome. I would request you to let us know your availabilities.

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee




--- End Original Email ---

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Hi Ashish,

It would be great to discuss building the ML model - I am free all day tomorrow, and Thursday and Friday afternoon.

The full CLU survey data which weâ€™re working with can be viewed through the following website (you can use my login credentials, username: ryanl, password: galaxies). This will allow you to view cropped images of the CLU data for a specified coordinate and fov.

http://gayatri.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/CLU/ImgsearchByCoord.cgi?ra=50&dec=50&con=0.2&fov=50.0&smoothval=2.0

I have also attached a csv file of the HASH database below, containing all known planetary nebulae. I have found it useful to use the above website to see what known PNe look like in the CLU data (especially the fainter objects) to investigate how to improve the current algorithmâ€™s recall (the fraction of known PNe recovered by the algorithm).

ï¿¼


With regards to SAM, the following authors fine-tuned SAM on medical images, resulting in some performance increases:

https://openreview.net/pdf?id=BNrWHF5ZlC

The issue with SAM is that it only allows points and boxes as prompts, with no natural language prompting. It either outputs prompt-based masks, or unprompted masks (produces one masks for every object identified in an image). My intuition suggests weâ€™d have to generate unprompted masks for our use-case.

An issue Iâ€™ve been facing in general with the current algorithm is the shear amount of junk detection. This has primarily been due to unmasked stars which remain after subtraction (due to poor chip quality on the edges), cosmic rays, and various other transient phenomena.

I have 5 weeks left on SURF and would appreciate if you could set me concrete goals to complete each week.

Let me know your thoughts.

Many thanks,
Ryan

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Hi Dave,

I had a few questions about this code. I am trying to write a function that takes as input an ra and dec, and as output spits out all file paths for chip images containing that coordinate, which I believe your code also does - I just donâ€™t understand a few things.

How does the AllHaWCSupCals_final.fits file contain all the data in the survey? This doesnâ€™t seem possible given itâ€™s only 90MB in size.

It seems you are using decmin, decmax, etc to judge whether a point lies in a chip image. However, this doesnâ€™t take into account that the chip edges may not be aligned with the ra and dec axes, leading to cases where a point does not actually lie in the chip image though it lies in the ra and dec bounds. For example, if the chip image is tilted relative to the ra and dec grids.

Is there any other data other than the single epoch images that might be useful? I know about the stacked and AllHaWCSupCals_final files - are there any others I should know about?

Warm regards,
Ryan

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Dear Dave,

Soumyadeep and I were discussing whether a new star crossmatching feature on the website would help with manual inspection. We were thinking of including another line in the top left information box, containing data from the PS and Gaia surveys (True if the object crossmatches with a star in the survey, False if not). At the moment it seems the majority of false positives are stars - crossmatching with PS and Gaia (or any other complete star survey that goes down to ~19 mag) could help with this.

We can keep the crossmatching distance low since stars are compact and the coordinates outputted by our algorithm seem quite accurate (although an issue could be a detection involving a cluster of stars).

Wanted to hear your thoughts and whether this would be feasible to implement?

Warm regards,
Ryan

You are writing an email. Context: Recipient: dcook@ipac.caltech.edu; Subject: Re: Nebula candidate images for manual inspection; Date: 2025-07-25T00:09:29-07:00

This is a reply to an email from dcook@ipac.caltech.edu dated 2025-07-18T18:17:31+00:00 with subject 'Re: Nebula candidate images for manual inspection':
--- Original Email ---From: dcook@ipac.caltech.eduSubject: Re: Nebula candidate images for manual inspectionDate: 2025-07-18T18:17:31+00:00
Content:
Hello,

Here is the lines of code I used to find the images in the â€œAll Ha Imagesâ€ website I showed today. Iâ€™ve left the stackimages lines in as I remember that checking for those that straddle RA may also be necessary for the single epoch images; depends if that is in the test area. Let me know if you donâ€™t have the AllHaWCSupCals_final.fits file...

Send me the CSV output of your code and the directory path of the images on gayatri.

Cheers,
Dave


Code:

    ra=coordin.ra.deg
    dec=coordin.dec.deg
    galb=coordin.galactic.b.deg
    gall=coordin.galactic.l.deg

    ramin=ra-radsearch
    ramax=ra+radsearch
    decmin=dec-radsearch
    decmax=dec+radsearch

    #load detection limits and coord limits table
    allimgs=Table.read('/data/dcook/CLU/calibration/withPS1/stats_AllHaWCSup/AllHaWCSupCals_final.fits')
    stackimgs=Table.read('/data/dcook/CLU/analysis/stack/ImgInfoStack.fits')
    
    #get images that overlap with input coord
    ind=np.where( (dec >= allimgs['decmin']) & (dec <= allimgs['decmax']) & (ra >= allimgs['ramin']) & (ra <= allimgs['ramax']) & (allimgs['badflag'] == 0))
    istack=np.where( ((dec >= stackimgs['dec4']) & (dec <= stackimgs['dec3'])) & 
                     (((ra >= stackimgs['ra1']) & (ra <= stackimgs['ra4'])) | 
                      ((ra >= stackimgs['ra2']) & (ra <= stackimgs['ra3']))) )

    #check if images straddle RA=0
    if (np.size(istack) == 0):
	istack=np.where( ((dec >= stackimgs['dec4']) & (dec <= stackimgs['dec3'])) & 
                	 (((ra >= stackimgs['ra1']) & (ra >= stackimgs['ra4']) & (stackimgs['ra4'] < stackimgs['ra1'])) | 
                	  ((ra <= stackimgs['ra1']) & (ra <= stackimgs['ra4']) & (stackimgs['ra4'] < stackimgs['ra1'])) | 
			  ((ra >= stackimgs['ra2']) & (ra >= stackimgs['ra3']) & (stackimgs['ra3'] < stackimgs['ra2'])) |
			  ((ra <= stackimgs['ra2']) & (ra <= stackimgs['ra3']) & (stackimgs['ra3'] < stackimgs['ra2']))) )     
    
    if (np.size(ind) == 0):
        ind=np.where( ((dec >= allimgs['decmin']) & (dec <= allimgs['decmax']) & (allimgs['badflag'] == 0)) & 
                      (((ra >= allimgs['ramin']) & (ra >= allimgs['ramax']) & (allimgs['ramax'] < allimgs['ramin'])) | 
                       ((ra <= allimgs['ramin']) & (ra <= allimgs['ramax']) & (allimgs['ramax'] < allimgs['ramin']))) ) 

    if (dec > 88.):
        istack=np.where(stackimgs['dec3'] > 87.5)
    
    
    stacks=stackimgs[istack]
    nstacks=np.size(stacks)
    fields=allimgs[ind]
    nfields=np.size(fields)


> On Jul 16, 2025, at 4:05â€¯PM, Bhattacharjee, Soumyadeep <sbhatta2@caltech.edu> wrote:

> Hello Dave,
> 
> Ryan has the first set of candidate images. Will it be possible for you to upload them to the portal if he sends them to you (maybe as a zip file)? 
> 
> With regards,
> Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee


--- End Original Email ---

You are writing an email. Context: Recipient: sbhatta2@caltech.edu; Subject: Re: Ryan's SURF Project - searching for (planetary) nebula in CLU Ha survey; Date: 2025-06-04T22:55:41+01:00

This is a reply to an email from sbhatta2@caltech.edu dated 2025-06-03T23:35:24+00:00 with subject 'Ryan's SURF Project - searching for (planetary) nebula in CLU Ha survey':
--- Original Email ---From: sbhatta2@caltech.eduSubject: Ryan's SURF Project - searching for (planetary) nebula in CLU Ha surveyDate: 2025-06-03T23:35:24+00:00
Content:
Hello Ryan, Dave, Ashish,

Hope you are doing well.

Ryan:

I would like to introduce you to Dr. Dave Cook and Dr. Ashish Mahabal who will help us with our project this summer. Dave is an astronomer at IPAC and he is in charge of the CLU Ha data. So for any questions related to the data, we will go to him. He has extensive experience in mining the data and is extremely knowledgeable about the various methods that one can use to hunt for diffused and extended sources.

Ashish is an expert in data science and machine learning in Cahill. He is the ML lead for various projects including the Zwicky Transient Facility. He will help us come up with a suitable ML algorithm to hunt for PNe in CLU data.

Dave, Ashish:

Please e-meet Ryan Lin, an Oxford sophomore majoring in physics. He will be a SURF student under Shri, working with me on finding nebulae from CLU Ha data. He has an impressive academic track record and has good knowledge in both astronomy and ML. He will be starting here the end of this month.

I am attaching here the SURF proposal for your reference. Section 3 in the proposal contains the initial plan that we had discussed. It also has the ML reference for planetary nebula that we had in mind (Sun et al. 2024), which has been used on VPHAS+ data.

I will try to meet with Ashish and Dave sometime soon to discuss some of the basics of the project and work out some preliminary plan. I would also request Dave to let me and Ryan know what we should do to get Ryan access to the data and my codes on Gayatri.

Looking forward to working together!

With regards,
Soumyadeep Bhattacharjee





--- End Original Email ---

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Dear all,

Nice to meet you all and very excited to work with you this summer!

In general, Iâ€™m very interested in using machine learning and computational methods to accelerate scientific research, especially with the significant improvements in LLM capabilities recently - Iâ€™d be very eager to work on additional opportunities to do so during the project alongside developing the PNe ML algorithm.

In particular, I think using LLM agents to automate some of the researcher workflow (e.g. object detection, identification, follow-up observations, hypothesis generation, etc) could be worthwhile. Just throwing an idea out there - let me know if you have any better thoughts!

Warm regards,
Ryan

metadata.subject: Re: Ryan's SURF Project - searching for (planetary) nebula in CLU Ha survey

This is a reply to an email from krishna@oxfounders.org dated 2025-04-18T14:22:04+00:00 with subject 'Hackathon follow-up - EWOR seminar opportunity':
--- Original Email ---From: krishna@oxfounders.orgSubject: Hackathon follow-up - EWOR seminar opportunityDate: 2025-04-18T14:22:04+00:00
Content:
Dear Hackathon Participant,

I am reaching out because the partners of EWOR (https://www.ewor.com/), an early-stage incubator programme and fund offered to give seminars for our hackathon participants on specific topics that could help you to take your project further. I thought this could be a great opportunity for you to get a perspective on not just the tech, but the entrepreneurial aspects of your work. The partners of EWOR are seasoned entrepreneurs, and frequently hold webinars for those interested to start their own company.

If you and your team are interested in learning more about EWOR, or a specific topic, please reply to this email, and send me your:
- names (+ LinkedIn if you have one),
- email addresses,
- the topic that you would be interested in learning more about.

Hopefully this will be a useful opportunity for you to take your project further.

All the best,
Greta
(President @ OxFounders)


--- End Original Email ---

--- Your reply to the original email ---
Names: Ryan Lin, Suleiman Mahmood, Azka Adziman
Email Addresses: ccâ€™ed
Topics Interested In: Fundraising, Machine Learning, Hardware Startups, LLM Inference, LLM-Specialised Chips
